abstract.p: Dr Ronald Halweil letter says medical community needs to practice preventive medicine by addressing lifestyle choices that are causing more than 90 percent of diabetes cases (Aug 24 article)

block.p: Re ''Diabetes Rises; Doctors Foresee a Harsh Impact'' (front page, Aug. 24): Since 90 to 95 percent of diabetes is lifestyle related, it would appear that we have a wonderful opportunity to practice preventive medicine. But will we?

Re ''Diabetes Rises; Doctors Foresee a Harsh Impact'' (front page, Aug. 24): Since 90 to 95 percent of diabetes is lifestyle related, it would appear that we have a wonderful opportunity to practice preventive medicine. But will we?

This epidemic of increased eating of high-calorie foods combined with decreased physical activity needs to be actively confronted by the medical community and government. There are clear parallels to the smoking epidemic. It took two generations of smokers to produce an explosion of respiratory cancer and emphysema, and we failed to take early decisive action. Only now are concerted efforts to reduce smoking through increased taxation and antismoking advertisements starting to work.

At some point the economics of the diabetes epidemic will force the issue as our medical system runs out of money for the dialysis units, medications and other treatments needed to sustain the new sick patients.
RONALD HALWEIL, M.D. Bayonne, N.J., Aug. 25, 2000
